Package infodynamics.utils

Class MatrixUtils

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.utils.MatrixUtils
  • public class MatrixUtils
extends java.lang.Object
    Utilities for computations on arrays and matrices of data. Matrices are represented as either one-dimensional arrays of int[] or double[], or two-dimensional arrays of double[][] or int[][] - it is assumed that all multidimensional matrices have consistent lengths in each dimension matrix[i].
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

      static double[][] CholeskyDecomposition​(double[][] A)  
      static double[][] CholeskyDecomposition​(double[][] A, double tol)
      Make the Cholesky decomposition L of a given input matrix A, where: A is symmetric and positive definite (has full rank) A = L L^T (L^T is the transpose of L - here A has real entries only, though a Cholesky decomposition is possible with complex entries) L is a lower triangular matrix We perform the decomposition using the Cholesky–Banachiewicz algorithm, computing L from the top left, row by row (see wikipedia)

      • reorderDataForVariables

        public static double[][] reorderDataForVariables​(double[][] inputValues,
                                                 int[][] reordering)
        Return data[x][y]: - y==0: inputValues[x][0] - y>0: inputValues[reordering[y-1][x]][y]
        Parameters:
        inputValues - holds the raw data values
        reordering - outlines how to rearrange the raw data values for each variable or column. First index is variable or column number. Reorderings may be supplied for all of the columns of the inputValues, or for one less than all of the columns, in which case the first column is not reordered. Second index is for the row number or time step. The value at that point states which row number to pull the data from.
        Returns:

      • makeDelayEmbeddingVector

        public static int[][] makeDelayEmbeddingVector​(int[] data,
                                               int k,
                                               int startKthPoint,
                                               int numEmbeddingVectors)
                                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Constructs numEmbeddingVectors embedding vectors of size k for the data, with the first embedding vector having it's last time point at t=startKthPoint
        Parameters:
        data - time series data
        k - embedding length
        startKthPoint - last time point of the first embedding vector (i.e. use k-1 if you want to go from the start)
        numEmbeddingVectors - the number of embedding vectors to return (i.e. use data.length-k+1 if you go from the start and want all of them extracted)
        Returns:
        a 2D array of k-length embedding vectors.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • makeDelayEmbeddingVector

        public static double[][] makeDelayEmbeddingVector​(double[] data,

                                                  int numEmbeddingVectors)
                                           throws java.lang.Exception

        Parameters:
        data - time series data
        k - embedding length
        startKthPoint - last time point of the first embedding vector (i.e. use k-1 if you want to go from the start)

        java.lang.Exception

      • makeDelayEmbeddingVector

        public static int[][] makeDelayEmbeddingVector​(int[] data,
                                               int k,
                                               int tau,
                                               int startKthPoint,
                                               int numEmbeddingVectors)
                                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Constructs numEmbeddingVectors embedding vectors of size k for the data, with embedding delay tau between each time sample for the vectors, with the first embedding vector having it's last time point at t=startKthPoint
        Parameters:
        data - time series data
        k - embedding length
        tau - embedding delay between each point in the original time series selected into each embedding vector
        startKthPoint - last time point of the first embedding vector (i.e. use (k-1)*tau if you want to go from the start)
        numEmbeddingVectors - the number of embedding vectors to return (i.e. use data.length-(k-1)*tau if you go from the start and want all of them extracted)
        Returns:
        a 2D array of k-length embedding vectors.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • makeDelayEmbeddingVector

        public static double[][] makeDelayEmbeddingVector​(double[][] data,
                                                  int k)
        Constructs all embedding vectors of k time points for the data, including all multivariate values at each time point. Will be data.length - k + 1 of these vectors returned
        Parameters:
        data - 2D time series data (time is first second, second is variable number), all of which is embedded

      • makeDelayEmbeddingVector

        public static double[][] makeDelayEmbeddingVector​(double[][] data,
                                                  int k,
                                                  int startKthPoint,
                                                  int numEmbeddingVectors)
                                           throws java.lang.Exception
        Constructs numEmbeddingVectors embedding vectors of k time points for the data, including all multivariate values at each time point. Return only a subset, with the first embedding vector having it's last time point at t=startKthPoint
        Parameters:
        data - 2D time series data (time is first second, second is variable number), all of which is embedded
        k - embedding length (i.e. number of time extractions for each vector)
        startKthPoint - last time point of the first embedding vector (i.e. use k-1 if you want to go from the start)
        numEmbeddingVectors - the number of embedding vectors to return (i.e. use data.length-k+1 if you go from the start and want all of them extracted)
        Returns:
        a 2D array of embedding vectors, which are each of length k x data[0].length.

      • makeDelayEmbeddingVector

        public static double[][] makeDelayEmbeddingVector​(double[][] data,
                                                  int k,
                                                  int tau,

                                                  int numEmbeddingVectors)
                                           throws java.lang.Exception
        Constructs numEmbeddingVectors embedding vectors of k time points for the data, including all multivariate values at each time point, with embedding delay tau between each time sample for the vectors, with the first embedding vector having it's last time point at t=startKthPoint

      • makeDelayEmbeddingVector

        public static double[][] makeDelayEmbeddingVector​(double[][] data,
                                                  int column,
                                                  int k,
                                                  int tau,
                                                  int startKthPoint,
                                                  int numEmbeddingVectors)
                                           throws java.lang.Exception
        Constructs numEmbeddingVectors embedding vectors of k time points for a single column of the data, with embedding delay tau between each time sample for the vectors, with the first embedding vector having it's last time point at t=startKthPoint
        Parameters:
        data - 2D time series data (time is first second, second is variable number), only one particular column of which is embedded
        column - the column index to embed
        k - embedding length (i.e. number of time extractions for each vector)
        tau - embedding delay between each point in the original time series selected into each embedding vector
        startKthPoint - last time point of the first embedding vector (i.e. use k-1 if you want to go from the start)
        numEmbeddingVectors - the number of embedding vectors to return (i.e. use data.length-k+1 if you go from the start and want all of them extracted)
        Returns:
        a 2D array of numEmbeddingVectors embedding vectors, which are each of length k.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • covarianceMatrix

        public static double[][] covarianceMatrix​(double[][] data1,
                                          double[][] data2)
        Compute the covariance matrix between all column pairs (variables) in the multivariate data set, which consists of two separate multivariate vectors.
        Parameters:
        data1 - multivariate array of data; first index is time, second is variable number
        data2 - a second multivariate array of data, which can be though of as extensions of rows of the first.
        Returns:
        covariance matrix, where the columns of dat1 are numbered first, and the columns of data2 after that.

      • covarianceMatrix

        public static double[][] covarianceMatrix​(double[][] data1,
                                          double[][] data2,
                                          int delay)
        Compute the covariance matrix between all column pairs (variables) in the multivariate data set, which consists of two separate multivariate vectors.
        Parameters:
        data1 - multivariate array of data; first index is time, second is variable number
        data2 - a second multivariate array of data, which can be thought of as extensions of rows of the first.
        delay - compute the lagged covariance of the given delay from data1 to data2 (assumes delay >= 0); i.e. compute correlation between data1[x] and data2[x+delay].
        Returns:
        covariance matrix, where the columns of data1 are numbered first, and the columns of data2 after that.

      • covarianceMatrix

        public static double[][] covarianceMatrix​(double[][] data1,
                                          double[][] data2,
                                          double[][] data3)
        Compute the covariance matrix between all column pairs (variables) in the multivariate data set, which consists of three separate multivariate vectors.
        Parameters:
        data1 - multivariate array of data; first index is time, second is variable number
        data2 - a second multivariate array of data, which can be thought of as extensions of rows of the first.
        data2 - a third multivariate array of data, which can be thought of as extensions of rows of the first and second.
        Returns:
        covariance matrix, where the columns of data1 are numbered first, the columns of data2 after that, and finally the columns of data3.

      • removeFromCovarianceMatrix

        public static void removeFromCovarianceMatrix​(double[][] covariances,
                                              double[][] data1,
                                              double[][] data2,
                                              double[][] data3,
                                              int[] columnsFrom1,
                                              int[] columnsFrom2,
                                              int[] columnsFrom3,
                                              double[] prevMeans1,
                                              double[] prevMeans2,
                                              double[] prevMeans3,
                                              int removeFromIndex,
                                              int numIndicesToRemove,
                                              int currentNumPointsInCov)
        Update the covariance matrix between all column pairs (variables) in the multivariate data set, which consists of three separate multivariate vectors, by removing the contribution of certain rows of data.
        Parameters:
        covariances - current covariance matrix, is updated by this method; The columns of data1 are numbered first, the columns of data2 after that, and finally the columns of data3.
        data1 - multivariate array of data; first index is time, second is variable number
        data2 - a second multivariate array of data, which can be thought of as extensions of rows of the first.
        data3 - a third multivariate array of data, which can be thought of as extensions of rows of the first and second.
        columnsFrom1 - array indicating which columns of variable 1 to use
        columnsFrom2 - array indicating which columns of variable 2 to use
        columnsFrom3 - array indicating which columns of variable 3 to use
        prevMeans1 - array of previous means for all columns of data1
        prevMeans2 - array of previous means for all columns of data2
        prevMeans3 - array of previous means for all columns of data3
        removeFromIndex - which sample (row) index to start removing contributions from
        numIndicesToRemove - how many rows to remove contributions from
        currentNumPointsInCov - how many samples the covariance is currently computed from

      • computeCovarianceMatrixRemoval

        public static double computeCovarianceMatrixRemoval​(double[][] data1,
                                                    double[][] data2,
                                                    int columnFor1,
                                                    int columnFor2,
                                                    double prevMean1,

                                                    int prevNumberSamples,
                                                    int removeFromIndex,
                                                    int numIndicesToRemove)
        Compute the subtraction required as part of an update to the covariance matrix of data1 and data2, by removing the contribution of certain rows of data.

        data2 - a second multivariate array of data, which can be thought of as extensions of rows of the first.

        columnFor2 - indicates which column of variable 2 to use
        prevMean1 - current mean of variable 1's column
        prevMean2 - current mean of variable 2's column
        prevNumberSamples - current number of samples in use
        removeFromIndex - which sample (row) index to start removing contributions from
        numIndicesToRemove - how many rows to remove contributions from

      • determinant

        public static double determinant​(double[][] matrix)

      • CholeskyDecomposition

        public static double[][] CholeskyDecomposition​(double[][] A)
                                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • CholeskyDecomposition

        public static double[][] CholeskyDecomposition​(double[][] A,
                                               double tol)
                                        throws java.lang.Exception

        Make the Cholesky decomposition L of a given input matrix A, where:

        1. A is symmetric and positive definite (has full rank)
        2. A = L L^T (L^T is the transpose of L - here A has real entries only, though a Cholesky decomposition is possible with complex entries)
        3. L is a lower triangular matrix
        We perform the decomposition using the Cholesky–Banachiewicz algorithm, computing L from the top left, row by row (see wikipedia)

        This method has been adapted from the JAMA project (public domain software)

        Parameters:
        A - input matrix
        tol - tolerance for non-positive definite exception (default is 10^-10 for signature without this parameter)
        Returns:
        L
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - when the matrix A is not square, is asymmetric, or not positive definite

      • invertSymmPosDefMatrix

        public static double[][] invertSymmPosDefMatrix​(double[][] A)
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute matrix inversion of a symmetric, positive definite matrix by using the Cholesky Decomposition L of the matrix A. Since A = L L^T, then A^-1 = (L^T)^-1 L^-1, and the inverses of
        Parameters:
        A - matrix to be inverted
        Returns:
        the inverse of A
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - when the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite
        See Also:
        CholeskyDecomposition(double[][])

      • solveViaCholeskyResult

        public static double[][] solveViaCholeskyResult​(double[][] L,
                                                double[][] B)

        Solve A*X = B, where A = L*L^T via Cholesky decomposition.

        This method has been adapted from the JAMA project (public domain software)

        Parameters:
        L - Cholesky decomposition of the matrix A
        B - matrix with as many rows as A and any number of columns
        Returns:
        X so that A*X = B
        See Also:
        CholeskyDecomposition(double[][])

      • determinantSymmPosDefMatrix

        public static double determinantSymmPosDefMatrix​(double[][] A)
                                          throws java.lang.Exception

        Compute determinant(A), where A = L*L^T via Cholesky decomposition is a symmetric, positive definite matrix.

        This is an efficient computation, since det(A) = det(L*L^T) = det(L)*det(L^T) and L is triangular so det(L) is just the product along the diagonal

        Parameters:
        A - symmetric, positive definite matrix to take the determinant of
        Returns:
        the determinant of A
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - when the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite

      • determinantViaCholeskyResult

        public static double determinantViaCholeskyResult​(double[][] L)

        Compute determinant(A), where A = L*L^T via Cholesky decomposition is a symmetric, positive definite matrix.

        This is an efficient computation, since det(A) = det(L*L^T) = det(L)*det(L^T) and L is triangular so det(L) is just the product along the diagonal

        Parameters:
        L - Cholesky decomposition L of the symmetric positive definite matrix A
        Returns:
        det(A)
        See Also:
        CholeskyDecomposition(double[][])

      • makeCholeskyOfIndependentComponents

        public static double[][] makeCholeskyOfIndependentComponents​(double[][] covariance,
                                                             java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> variableCandidates,
                                                             java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> fixedCandidates)
                                                      throws java.lang.Exception
        Attempts to produce a Cholesky decomposition of the subset of rows/columns of the given covariance matrix (composed of both fixedCandidates and variableCandidates). If some of the variables amongst the variableCandidates are linearly dependent (including with the fixedCandidates), it removes them from the subset variableCandidates until a linearly independent set is found, then the decomposition is returned for that set (and the set is updated in the variableCandidates list). If there are no elements left in variableCandidates that are independent from the fixedCandidates (or if fixedCandidates is empty then no candidates with any variance), null is returned. If a dependency is found amongst the fixedCandidates alone, an Exception is thrown.
        Parameters:
        covariance -
        variableCandidates -
        Returns:
        Cholesky decomposition, for the (final) fixedCandidates and then variableCandidates.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for asymmetric and non-square matrices, or a NonPositiveDefiniteMatrixException if the error is generated by rows from the fixedCandidates

      • doubleToIntArray

        public static int[] doubleToIntArray​(double[] array)
        Convert a double array to an int array. This is designed specifically for use of the toolkit in Octave where all native arrays are considered as doubles for Java. To use an integer 1D array (to supply to a java method), one must first create the native Octave 1D array, then create a java 1D Double array, then use this method to convert that java 1D Double array to a java 1D integer array.
        Parameters:
        array -
        Returns:

      • doubleToIntArray

        public static int[][] doubleToIntArray​(double[][] array)
        Convert a 2D double array to an int array. This is designed specifically for use of the toolkit in Octave where all native arrays are considered as doubles for Java. To use an integer 2D array (to supply to a java method), one must first create the native Octave 2D array, then create a java 2D Double array, then use this method to convert that java 2D Double array to a java 2D integer array.
        Parameters:
        array -
        Returns:
